comments.body: It would be good to put a descriptive comment before this function. The comment should describe what the function's purpose is, and what it does at a very high level. The comment at the start of the function body is too low level, and reads more like a program itself than is good.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +312,316 @@ */
static void
arr_insert_loop(char *mptr, char *vptr, char *input_data, char *zero,
                char *avals_data, int melsize, int delsize, int objarray,
                int totmask, int numvals, int nd, npy_intp *instrides,

comments.body: while I'd say its a compiler issue this code optimizes worse than jaime's with gcc, though it probably makes no real difference in performance (just one extra pipelineable mov)
Excuse my ignorance, but what's the source of the "extra pipelineable mov"?

I've been tempted to look at the generated code. The one with less indexing should have more register operations and fewer loads into the fpu registers, but much depends on how clever the compiler is in dealing with the indexing. What optimization level did you use?

don't know, the code is semantically identical I think, maybe integer overflow flags or some details concerning sequence points could cause the difference.
What counts is readability in which respect I'm fine with both approaches.

For instance, here is the third loop with `-O3`

```
.L15:
    addq    $8, %rdx
    movsd   -8(%rdx), %xmm0
    ucomisd %xmm1, %xmm0
    ja  .L24
    movapd  %xmm0, %xmm1
.L14:
    cmpq    %rax, %rdx
    jne .L15
```

Compare to

```
.L55:
    xorl    %eax, %eax
.L41:
    rep ret
    .p2align 4,,10
    .p2align 3
.L60:
    cmpl    %edx, %esi
    jle .L54
    addl    $1, %edx
    movslq  %edx, %rax
    leaq    (%rdi,%rax,8), %rax
    ucomisd (%rax), %xmm1
    jbe .L48
    jmp .L55
    .p2align 4,,10
    .p2align 3
.L47:
    movsd   (%rax), %xmm0
    addq    $8, %rax
    addl    $1, %edx
    ucomisd (%rax), %xmm0
    ja  .L55
```

This with gcc version 4.8.2 20131212 (Red Hat 4.8.2-7) (GCC) .

@jaimefrio Don't worry, we're just playing here, although there is much to learn be reading way too much generated assembly ;)

I got this using minimal loop:

```
  70:   f2 0f 10 07             movsd  (%rdi),%xmm0
  74:   48 83 c7 08             add    $0x8,%rdi
  78:   66 0f 2e 07             ucomisd (%rdi),%xmm0
  7c:   77 12                   ja     90 <g+0x40>
  7e:   48 39 c7                cmp    %rax,%rdi
  81:   75 ed                   jne    70 <g+0x20>
```

vs yours:

```
  20:   48 83 c7 08             add    $0x8,%rdi
  24:   f2 0f 10 47 f8          movsd  -0x8(%rdi),%xmm0
  29:   66 0f 2e c1             ucomisd %xmm1,%xmm0
  2d:   77 11                   ja     40 <f+0x40>
  2f:   66 0f 28 c8             movapd %xmm0,%xmm1
  33:   48 39 c7                cmp    %rax,%rdi
  36:   75 e8                   jne    20 <f+0x20>
```

though the longer code is probably faster as avoids a memory to register move for a register register move the latter has lower latency even if its in the L1 cache. So you win :)
The compare register to memory `ucomisd (%rdi),%xmm0` in the first example is also probably slower than the register to register  `ucomisd %xmm1,%xmm0` in the second.
